<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Cistophoric Tetradrachm (Coin) Portraying Mark Antony  
39/38 B.C., issued by Mark Antony  
Silver; diam. 3 cm; 11.52 g  
Mint: Ephesus (probably)  
Obverse: Head of Mark Antony right, ivy wreath, lituus (below); leaf and flower border  
Inscribed: M ANTONINVS.IMP.  
COS.DESIG.ITER.ET.TERT  
Reverse: Head of Octavia over cista mystica, serpents on each side  
Inscribed: III.VIR / R.P.C. (outward, to left and right)  
RPC I 2201; BMCRR East 134; axis: 11:00  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of William F. Dunham, 1920.2828

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">The so-called cistophoric tetradrachm was the coinage of the kingdom of Pergamum from the second century B.C.; the denomination and type continued into the Roman era. Politics, domestic drama, and myth come together in a remarkable way on this coin.

After the battle of Philippi in 42 B.C., Octavian and Mark Antony divided the empire between them, sidelining the third triumvir, Lepidus. Antony retained command in the East; Octavian held Rome. Tension between them was aggravated by the maneuvers of a remarkable woman: Fulvia, Antony’s wife, who waged war in Italy against Octavian. To complicate matters, Fulvia’s daughter Clodia was Octavian’s wife. Antony and Octavian met to defuse the situation, resulting in the Treaty of Brindisium in 40 B.C. As part of the accord, Octavian divorced Clodia; Antony, free of Fulvia (who had conveniently just died), married Octavian’s sister Octavia. The new happy couple returned to Athens, where Antony assumed the persona of New Dionysos, as had Hellenistic kings before him. Coins struck by Antony in the East present him as the beautiful young god whose death and rebirth was celebrated in the Dionysian Mysteries, and Octavia was his Ariadne. Octavia is probably the first actual Roman woman presented on a coin.

The obverse shows Antony’s chiseled features crowned by ivy while on the reverse, Octavia’s head floats eerily over the cista mystica—the chest or basket that held snakes for the sacred rituals. The juxtaposition of the proper and decorous Octavia with the Bacchic Mysteries must have shocked Romans and thrilled Greeks. Shortly after this coin was minted, however, Antony resumed his relationship with Cleopatra VII of Egypt, and in 32 B.C. he divorced Octavia and sent agents to evict her from their home in Rome; the insult spurred her brother Octavian to read Antony’s will in public, revealing Antony’s intention to make Cleopatra and her sons his heirs. The battle of Actium would follow in a matter of months.

The obverse inscription—in Latin, not Greek—advertises Antony as imperator and as consul designate for the second (ITER[um]) and third (TERT[ius]) times. The designated consulships help to date this coin, since they were awarded in the Pact of Misenum (39 B.C.) at which Antony, Octavian, and Sextus Pompeius (see cat. 32, Denarius (Coin) Portraying Pompey the Great) brokered a power-sharing arrangement and agreed on the consulships for the coming years. The lituus below identifies him as augur. The reverse legend proclaims him triumvir rei publicae constituendae, “one of three men for [re]establishing the Republic.” But it was an empty phrase. By this date, Lepidus was out, Octavian had distanced himself from the triumvirate, and none of them had plans to reconstitute the Republic.  
Theresa Gross-Diaz

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Alexander the Great introduced a unified coinage based on the Athenian standard, but his successors tended to reduce the weight of his tetradrachm. The Attalid kings of Pergamum after 166 B.C. used the Ptolemaic standard of three drachms of silver in a new four-drachm denomination, called the “cistophore” because of the image of a cista mystica on the coin. See Kleiner and Noe, Early Cistophoric Coinage, esp. p. 125.

Wood, Imperial Women, pp. 43–51.

Bacchic rites had been outlawed in Rome in 186 B.C. (Livy, History of Rome 39.8–19); but by the time of Julius Caesar the mysteries were gaining interest again. See Kraemer, Her Share of the Blessings, esp. pp. 43–45.

Wood, Imperial Women, pp. 31–32. After Antony’s death Octavia raised her own children and those of Antony with Fulvia and with Cleopatra as well.

See Appian, Civil Wars 5.73. The circumstances, first of Antony’s campaign in Parthia, and then of his war with Octavian, prevented him from taking up the office either time. On the dating of the coin, see Wood, Imperial Women, p. 45.

He was appointed an augur in 49 B.C. For the importance of this position, see cat. 32, Denarius (Coin) Portraying Pompey the Great.
